Trump's second-old son, Eric, also addressed his father's conviction on X Thursday evening, writing, "May 30th, 2024 might be remembered as the day Donald J. Trump won the 2024 Presidential Election."
Lara Trump, Eric's wife and co-chair of the Republican National Convention, shared a link to Trump's campaign on her X account, along with the quote, "They're not coming after me, they're coming after you, I'm just in the way."
Trump was joined by several family members during trial for his hush money indictment, where he was accused of forging records in order to conceal a payment made to adult film actress Stormy Daniels during the 2016 election. Don Jr. has made several visits to the Manhattan courthouse, including sharing a video to TikTok on Wednesday of him and the former president enjoying snacks while the jury deliberated. Eric and Lara Trump were spotted at the courthouse while closing arguments were presented in the case on Tuesday, alongside the former president's youngest daughter, Tiffany Trump, and her husband, Michael Boulos.
Two family members were notably absent throughout the trial—former First Lady Melania Trump and Ivanka, the former president's eldest daughter who served as an adviser during his first term.
Ivanka Trump did not issue a formal statement regarding her father's conviction, but she did share a photo to her Instagram story Thursday night of her as a child sitting on the former president's lap. The caption written over the picture read, "I love you dad."
Newsweek has reached out to the offices of Ivanka and Melania Trump on Thursday for comment on the former president's verdict.
Trump's former press secretary, Stephanie Grisham, told CNN on Wednesday that it is likely the former president was bothered that his eldest daughter and wife did not show during the trial.
"That kind of thing would bother him," she said. "If Mrs. Trump wasn't at some event and it was really noted, he would definitely bring it up with her. So I'm sure in this context, it's definitely really bothering him."
Update 5/30/24, 9:33 p.m. ET: This story has been updated with additional information and background.

title: Michael Cohen Reacts to Donald Trump's New York Verdict
description: Michael Cohen issued a statement following the guilty verdict in former President Donald Trump's New York trial on Thursday.
content:
Michael Cohen issued a statement following the guilty verdict in former President Donald Trump's New York trial on Thursday.
Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, faced trial in New York City on 34 counts of falsifying business records related to a hush money payment allegedly made to adult film actor Stormy Daniels ahead of the 2016 presidential election. Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg alleged the payment was meant to prevent her from speaking publicly about her claims of having an affair with the former president.
On Thursday, a jury handed down a guilty verdict on all 34 felony counts following the trial, which lasted more than a month throughout April and May, while several states held their primary nominating contests.
"This was a disgrace. This was a rigged trial by a conflicted judge who was corrupt," Trump said outside the courtroom following the verdict. Trump, who has long denounced the prosecution as a "witch hunt," has said he is innocent of all charges in this case and other criminal and civil cases he is facing.
"Today is an important day for accountability and the rule of law. While it has been a difficult journey for me and my family, the truth always matters. I want to thank my attorneys Danya Perry and Joshua Kolb for their invaluable guidance and support throughout this process," the former Trump lawyer, who served a key witness for the prosecution in the case, told Newsweek in a text message.
Throughout the trial, Trump's defense attorneys sought to undermine Cohen's credibility, as he was a key witness for the prosecution. They highlighted previous lies he had admitted to and accused him of perjuring himself in the trial.
The charges stem from payments made by Cohen to adult performer Stephanie Clifford, better known by her stage name Stormy Daniels, in an attempt to silence her allegations of an affair with the former president.
Prosecutors argued that Trump orchestrated the payments and subsequent reimbursements to Cohen, disguising them as legal expenses to protect his 2016 campaign. Trump has maintained his innocence throughout the trial, calling the case a politically motivated "witch hunt," and that not even Mother Teresa couldn't beat the charges against him.
Following the verdict on Thursday, Trump posted to his social media platform Truth Social: "VICTORY ON NOVEMBER 5TH. SAVE AMERICA!!!"
"I'm a very innocent man, and it's okay, I'm fighting for our country. I'm fighting for our Constitution. Our whole country is being rigged right now," the former president said in a statement emailed to Newsweek.
"This was done by the Biden administration in order to wound or hurt an opponent, a political opponent. And I think it's just a disgrace. And we'll keep fighting. We'll fight till the end, and we'll win because our country has gone to hell."
President Joe Biden maintains that he does not get involved with the legal case his Justice Department is pursuing. The Manhattan prosecution was brought at the local level, and not under supervision of the Justice Department.
Many of Trump's Republican supporters took to social media to slam the prosecution and the verdict.
"Radical leftists & Deepstate Operatives have been orchestrating this SHAM trial from the beginning," Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Georgia Republican, wrote on X. "What do they do now that President Trump is leading in the polls, and their stunt is failing? You don't see this level of corruption in a banana republic, but it's happening in our own backyard."
"This verdict is the corrupt result of a corrupt trial, a corrupt judge, and a corrupt DA," Representative Matt Gaetz, a Florida Republican, wrote on X. "We will stand with President Trump now more than ever to save the country."
Update 05/30/24 6:49 p.m. ET: This article was updated with comment from Donald Trump.

title: Celebrities Speak Out About Donald Trump Trial Verdict
description: Former President Donald Trump's has become the first former U.S. president to be convicted of criminal charges, and the verdict has sparked a mixed reaction online from celebrities and notable figures.
content:
Former President Donald Trump's has become the first former U.S. president to be convicted of criminal charges, and the verdict has sparked a mixed reaction online from celebrities and notable figures.
Trump was found guilty on all 34 counts of falsifying business records in connection to a $130,000 hush money payment made to adult film star Stormy Daniels during the 2016 campaign. Trump pleaded not guilty to all charges against him in the indictment brought against him by the Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg. He will face sentencing on July 11.
"This was a disgrace," Trump said in a statement Thursday evening. "This was a rigged trial by a conflicted judge that was corrupt."
"The real verdict is going to be November 5 by the people," he added. "And they know what happened here, and everybody knows what happened here...I'm a very innocent man, and it's okay, I'm fighting for our country. I'm fighting for our Constitution. Our whole country is being rigged right now."
The 12-person jury's verdict garnered reaction from figures like Tucker Carlson, a conservative political commentator who said that Trump's conviction marks "the end of the fairest justice system in the world."
"Import the Third World, become the Third World," Carlson wrote on X, formerly Twitter. "That's what we just saw. This won't stop Trump. He'll win the election if he's not killed first. But it does mark the end of the fairest justice system in the world. Anyone who defends this verdict is a danger to you and your family."
Former Republican presidential candidate and Trump supporter Vivek Ramaswamy also rebuked Thursday's guilty verdict, writing on X, "Trump led criminal justice reform. Now he's suffering criminal *injustice* at the highest level."
"One of surprising effects of this sham verdict: more black voters will flock to Trump in droves & for good reason," Ramaswamy added. "I didn't think the Democrat Party would be so dumb, but here we are."
Donald Trump Jr., the former president's eldest son, posted, "Such bull****."
Other celebrities welcomed the conviction, including American actor Rob Reiner, who posted to X, "GUILTY!!!!!"
"Guilty on all counts," wrote Billy Baldwin, an American actor and producer. "E. Jean Carroll ✅ Stormy Daniels ✅ Election interference, espionage and inciting an insurrection coming up."
"Dear #MAGA," added author Don Winslow. "Guilty 34 times. All best, Don Winslow."
Former Minnesota Senator Al Franken, a Democrat, also celebrated Trump's guilty verdict but noted that the conviction also marks a "sad day" for the United States.
"This is a great day because justice prevailed; Trump was found guilty on all 34 counts," Franken wrote on X. "But a sad day because we have a former president who committed several crimes."
"If this had gotten out before the '16 election, if they hadn't paid off Stormy Daniels and Karen McDougall, I believe we would have avoided a Trump presidency," he added. "The job now is to prevent another Trump presidency."
Michael Cohen, Trump's former attorney who served as a key witness in the hush money trial, told Newsweek on Thursday that the former president's verdict "is an important day for accountability and the rule of law."
"While it has been a difficult journey for me and my family, the truth always matters," Cohen added. "I want to thank my attorneys Danya Perry and Joshua Kolb for their invaluable guidance and support throughout this process."
It's unclear if Trump's verdict will impact his chances for reelection. Some experts previously told Newsweek that his conviction could complicate his 2024 campaign. Polling has also indicated that a significant number of American voters will consider Trump's verdict when casting a ballot this November.
In one survey by Marquette Law School, which was conducted earlier this month while the hush money trial was ongoing, 44 percent of voters said that they would vote for the former president if he was found not guilty, while 38 percent said they would vote for President Joe Biden if Trump was acquitted.
However, in the case that Trump was found guilty, only 39 percent of those surveyed said they would vote for the former president, with 43 percent choosing Biden.
Update 5/30/24, 6:53 p.m. ET: This story has been updated with additional information and background.

title: Jury in Donald Trump Trial Reaches Verdict
description: A New York jury has reached a guilty verdict in the high-profile hush money case against former President Donald Trump, telling the judge they were ready to issue their decision on Thursday afternoon.
content:
A New York jury has reached a guilty verdict in the high-profile hush money case against former President Donald Trump, telling the judge they were ready to issue their decision on Thursday afternoon.
Trump was charged with 34 counts of falsifying business records related to a $130,000 payment to adult film star Stormy Daniels during the 2016 presidential campaign. The trial, which has garnered national attention, marks a historic moment in the legal troubles facing the former president as he seeks another term in office.
Donald Trump was found guilty on all charges and now faces potential prison sentence.
The charges stem from payments made by Trump's former attorney, Michael Cohen, to Daniels in an attempt to silence her allegations of an affair with the former president.
Prosecutors argued that Trump orchestrated the payments and subsequent reimbursements to Cohen, disguising them as legal expenses to protect his 2016 campaign. Trump has maintained his innocence throughout the trial, calling the case a politically motivated "witch hunt," and that not even Mother Teresa couldn't beat the charges against him.
The jury deliberated for two days, requesting to review key testimonies and the judge's instructions before reaching their decision. Judge Juan Merchan emphasized the importance of impartiality and instructed jurors to set aside personal biases.
He detailed the legal standards for the charges, explaining that the prosecution needed to prove Trump acted with intent to defraud and cover up another crime, such as a violation of election laws​​.
Prosecutors presented a series of documents and testimonies to establish a pattern of deceit. David Pecker, former CEO of American Media Inc., testified about the "catch-and-kill" scheme to suppress negative stories about Trump during the campaign. Cohen described his role in facilitating the payments and the efforts to keep them secret.
The former president's defense team focused on discrediting Cohen, labeling him as the "greatest liar of all time," and arguing that the payments were personal expenses unrelated to the campaign​​. Trump's lawyers had Cohen admit that he stole money from the Trump Organization and had a personal interest in the case.
Reactions to the trial have been polarized. Trump's supporters, including several prominent Republican figures, have denounced it as unfair and politically motivated.
"This is a direct violation of existing case law about jury instructions," South Dakota Governor Kristi Noem posted on X, formerly Twitter, echoing sentiments from other conservatives who believe the trial is a sham​​.
Legal experts and critics of Trump argue that the case demonstrates accountability and the importance of upholding the law, regardless of one's position.
"This case underscores that no one is above the law, not even a former president," a spokesperson from the New York Attorney General's office said.
As the country awaits the official announcement of the verdict, the implications of this trial are profound. A conviction could significantly affect Trump's political future and his ongoing presidential campaign.
President Joe Biden's administration has refrained from commenting directly on the case, but emphasized the importance of respecting the judicial process. However, his campaign took its most public stance yet when campaign officials and supporters made speeches outside the trial on Tuesday.
If convicted, Trump could face substantial fines and potentially jail time, though there is skepticism that the former president would actually be sentenced to prison.
Trump's legal team has already indicated plans to appeal any unfavorable verdict, promising to continue fighting the charges.

title: Brittney Griner Opens Up About Russia: 'Whole Life Flashing Before My Eyes'
description: Professional basketball player Brittney Griner opened up on Thursday's episode of "The View" about being detained in a Russian prison on smuggling charges after THC was found in her luggage at an airport.
content:
Professional basketball player Brittney Griner opened up on Thursday's episode of "The View" about being detained in a Russian prison on smuggling charges after THC was found in her luggage at an airport.
Griner described how she felt being stopped by airport security in Moscow.
"I was like, whole life flashing before my eyes kind of feeling. How could I have made this mistake? It was scary," Griner said.
She thought of ending her life when she was in captivity, but her family kept her going.
"I was at a really low moment," Griner said. "It was, I feel like, honestly the dirtiest I've ever felt. And I was just thinking, if I did do this, would they even release my body to my family? Would they hold on to me? I was already going through a lot, my family was going through a lot, and that thought right there kept me from doing that."
Griner was arrested in Russia for having less than a gram of medically prescribed THC in February 2022. She was sentenced to nine years in prison in August 2022. But U.S. officials arranged a trade for her release in December 2022.
Griner plays for the WNBA on the Phoenix Mercury. She has also played in China and Russia.
After being sentenced to nine years in prison, Griner was sent to one of the harshest penal colonies in Russia. Griner said it was "a different world."
"It was frightening. I didn't really understand anything," Griner said. "Because you don't know anything that's going on. You're just being pointed at and they don't even try to speak, they're just talking to you in Russian."
She recalled what it was like to finally touch down on American soil and reunite with her wife.
"I just remember grabbing her, holding her, whispering in her ear," Griner said.
Griner also had a message for people who have labeled her careless for forgetting she had THC in her luggage, which is not legal in Russia.
"People that call me careless, have you ever forgot your keys? Or where's my glasses? Everyone's made a mistake before," Griner said.
She also took offense to those who have called her unpatriotic for kneeling during the National Anthem. She said her dad was a veteran and worked in law enforcement.
"That was my hero. I wanted to be a cop. I didn't want to play basketball growing up," Griner said. "I wanted to be a cop and go into the military actually. And doesn't it make me more American that I'm demonstrating the protests? That's my right as an American, so for me to be called un-American, I was blown away at that."

title: Ukraine Receives New Arms Boost From Germany
description: German Defense Minister Boris Pistorius revealed a new $542 million arms package for Ukraine on Thursday while visiting the port city of Odesa.
content:
German Defense Minister Boris Pistorius revealed a new $542 million arms package for Ukraine on Thursday while visiting the port city of Odesa.
Pistorius' announcement was made alongside Ukrainian Defense Minister Rustem Umerov, who met with his German counterpart to discuss Kyiv's military needs. According to DW News, it is the third time that Pistorius has visited Ukraine since the start of Russia's invasion in February 2022.
"We will continue to support you in this defensive campaign," Pistorius said during his meeting with Umerov.
The package included fresh ammunition for the IRIS-T air defense system, which is capable of reaching short to medium ranges. DW News reported that the systems can intercept missiles up to 20 kilometers (12.4 miles) in altitude and 40 kilometers (24.8 miles) in distance.
Newsweek reached out to Ukraine's Defense Ministry via email for additional comment Thursday.
Pistorius announced over X, formerly Twitter, last week that Germany had provided another IRIS-T SLM and IRIS-T SLS "combined fire unit" to Kyiv's military. NATO allies have worked to bolster Ukraine's air defense capabilities in recent months amid an increase in Russian air strikes.
Sweden also pledged a military aid package worth more that $1.25 billion to Ukraine on Thursday, the largest that the country has provided to Kyiv to date. The package will include airborne surveillance and control aircraft, artillery and Sweden's "entire stock" of tracked armored personnel carriers.
Stockholm said on Thursday that the package will bring Ukraine's air defenses to a "completely new capability."
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez signed a bilateral security agreement with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky earlier this week that allocates $1.1 billion of Madrid's military aid to Kyiv in 2024. That package includes anti-aircraft missiles, Leopard tanks and ammunition, according to a report from the Associated Press.
Ukraine is also set to receive a large package from the United Kingdom in the coming weeks, which will include naval boats and weapons, air defense missiles, precision-guided missiles and combat vehicles. The package, announced by U.K. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak in late April, is worth $618 million, and brings the British aid total for the financial year to $3.71 billion.
After months of debate and delay, the United States' supplemental aid to Ukraine is set to begin reaching Ukraine's frontlines, although Mykhailo Podolyak, an advisor to Zelensky, told Bloomberg in an interview published Wednesday that the weaponry was taking "weeks" to reach where it is needed most along the line of contact.
The Institute for the Study of War (ISW) warned in its assessment of the Russia-Ukraine war on Wednesday that Russia was likely looking to take "advantageous" amid the delays in U.S.-provided aid to Kyiv.

title: Is Putin Facing Another 'Coup'? What We Know
description: Having solidified his leadership in what others have called "sham" elections, Russian President Vladimir Putin has made bold diplomatic gestures toward Chinese and Iranian leadership while continuing threats of nuclear war against Western opponents.
content:
Having solidified his leadership in what others have called "sham" elections, Russian President Vladimir Putin has made bold diplomatic gestures toward Chinese and Iranian leadership while continuing threats of nuclear war against Western opponents.
With Russia making recent gains in the war with Ukraine, it appears that Putin has been attempting to solidify his presence and reassert power.
However, the recent arrest of a senior Russian commander who criticized Russia's military and its treatment of soldiers in southern Ukraine has led to suggestions that Putin's influence was weakening and that he may be at risk of being toppled in a coup.
Major General Ivan Popov, who had headed Russia's 58th Army, was "arrested on suspicion of fraud," Russian state news agency Tass reported on May 21, citing a law enforcement spokesperson.
Popov was removed from his command in Ukraine's annexed southern Zaporizhzhia region in July 2023 after he criticized the Russian Defense Ministry for failing to provide sufficient support for the country's fighters.
Popov condemned what he called a "lack of counter-battery combat," too few resources to scout for artillery and the "mass deaths" of Russian soldiers.
In a recording published to social media by Russian MP and former military commander Andrei Gurulyov, Popov—appearing to be addressing his troops—said he had "raised a number of other problems" to the top of Russia's military command and was dismissed by then-Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu.
"The senior chiefs apparently sensed some kind of danger from me," Popov said.
This, entangled with other rumors, has led to online speculation that Putin is at risk of a military coup. But are any of these claims worth believing?
Popov's arrest did not happen in a vacuum. Earlier this month, Shoigu was fired while three of his deputies were said to have resigned the previous week.
Other arrests were made connected to a corruption scandal within the Defense Ministry. The head of personnel at Russia's Defense Ministry, Yuri Kuznetsov, was arrested on suspicion of bribery three weeks ago after more than $1 million in cash and valuables were discovered at his properties.
At least five people have been arrested in the scandal, including Deputy Minister Timur Ivanov, who has been in pre-trial detention on bribery charges since April 23 after he was accused of receiving bribes worth $11 million in the form of property services from a construction company in return for contracts. Ivanov denies the charges.
Earlier this week, it was reported that Vadim Shamarin, deputy chief of the Russian General Staff, had been arrested. Shamarin is reported to be a top aide to Russia's top general, Chief of the General Staff Valery Gerasimov.
Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov denied that the arrests were part of a campaign, telling reporters: "Of course, there is no talk of any campaigning here. It continues in all departments, be it either federal departments or at the municipal level."
These arrests, but particularly Popov's, began the speculative conversation. Trent Telenko, a former official at the Pentagon's Defense Contract Management Agency who has studied Russian military logistics, posted on X, formerly Twitter, on May 22 that the arrest of Popov was directly related to the idea of a coup purge.
Telenko wrote: "58th Army of the Southern Military District, Ivan Popov, was one of the few competent Russian flag ranks. His removal is about Putin 'Coup proofing' his military."
Igor Sushko, a Ukrainian military blogger and the executive director of the Wind of Change Research Group, has made a number of posts since the alleged "purge" began suggesting that the changes in the defense ministry were part of Putin's paranoid strategy.
Posting on May 24 Sushko said that Popov's arrest and the decision to keep him detained in prison was a sign of a "COUP RISK RISING IN RUSSIA" adding elsewhere that there were "whispers of a rebellion among the soldiers."
Other commentators, such as @generalsvr_en, have posted claims that "General Staff are preparing to take action to overthrow the current government in #Russia."
"Allegedly, plans for a "march on Moscow" similar to the rebellion of PMC Wagner under the leadership of Yevgeny Prigozhin have been developed," they added in a post on May 23.
"The speakers assured that according to the conspirators' plan, several columns of military personnel with equipment were to move towards Moscow from several regions, and the implementation of these plans was scheduled for early June."
The echoes of Prigozhin's attempted "mutiny" in 2023 have not faded and such a wide-ranging change of hands and arrests at least begs the question of what discontent lies within the ranks of the Kremlin and the Russian military.
However, judging by what's been said and the credibility of some of the commentators making the claims, the notion of a coup is not particularly strong.
The reason for Shoigu's sacking is unknown, but it has been speculated that the appointment of Andrei Belousov, a former deputy prime minister who has no military background, is part of Putin's strategy to improve the efficiency of Russia's war economy as its army seeks to push further into Ukraine.
The background to Timur Ivanov's arrest has followed investigation and suspicion since December 2022. The anti-corruption organization FBK, founded by the late Russian opposition figure Alexei Navalny, who died in custody in February, alleged that Ivanov and his family lived an opulent life abroad that included luxury cars, jewelry and expensive real estate.
Navalny's team also said that Ivanov had profited from construction projects in the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, which fell under Moscow's control after a monthslong siege.
Igor Sushko, who has also talked up speculation of a "coup," has argued that none of the "purges" have anything to do with Navalny's previous investigations.
In a post on May 13, he wrote: "Reality check: None of the purges at the top of Russia's Defence Ministry are the result of Navalny team's corruption investigations. Corruption is just a public excuse in some instances. Putin was the ultimate and knowing benefactor of all this corruption."
However, all of the discussion seems to be, at best, informed speculation. While the change in top brass is piquing interest, no real evidence beyond the announcements of arrests and firings cements the claim that a coup is afoot.
Some of the commentators who pushed the theory have also shared misleading information in the past. For instance, Newsweek has previously fact-checked claims made by Igor Sushko.
User @generalsvr_en, otherwise known as General SVR, has also previously shared baseless and dramatic rumors about Putin having died and being replaced with body doubles.
Newsweek has contacted a media representative at the Kremlin via email for comment.

title: Will Joe Biden Close US Border? What We Know
description: President Joe Biden is considering executive action to close the southern U.S. border, according to recent reports. Here is what we know.
content:
President Joe Biden is considering executive action to close the southern U.S. border, according to recent reports. Here is what we know.
Multiple media outlets have said the president is looking at using Section 212 (f) of the U.S. Code, which allows him to "suspend the entry" of certain groups when the number of crossings reaches a certain size.
There has been no official announcement from the White House but Biden and several governors have been fairly open about the fact the Government is looking into what it can do.
At the end of February, after Biden's bipartisan bill collapsed when Republicans backed away from the agreement, the President reportedly told the National Governors Association he was exploring executive actions. The Bill would have, in theory, restricted illegal border crossings, made it more difficult to apply for asylum and speed up deportations while simultaneously making more visas available legally.
Utah Gov. Spencer Cox, the Republican chair of the association said: "[Biden] did say that he has been working with his attorneys, trying to understand what executive action would be upheld in the courts and would be constitutional, and that he seemed a little frustrated that he was not getting answers from attorneys that he felt he could take the kind of actions that he wanted to."
Colorado Gov. Jared Polis, the Democratic vice-chair of the governors' group, said governors got a "general sense that they're looking into whatever they can do on the executive side."
The administration has since gone fairly quiet on its plan. "They're in that pretty classic mode of, nothing is on fire right now," an immigration advocate who was working with the government told Politico earlier this week.
A White House official reportedly responded to Politico, saying the administration could still go ahead with the move in the coming weeks.
Newsweek has contacted the administration via its press office for comment.
White House correspondent for PBS NewsHour, Laura Barrón-López, reported that sources have told her the close-border action could come after the Mexican election on June 2.
She said: "It's going to be expected to be similar language that was used in the bipartisan Senate border deal that failed.
"For example, if there is an average of 5,000 migrants encountered each day over the course of seven days, then this authority would be triggered, and President Biden would be able to shutdown the border until those encounters fall.
"Now, the White House and a White House official told me that no final decisions have been made about an executive action that is potentially being considered."
She went on to mention activists' concerns that measures like this, which usually do not apply to unaccompanied children for humanitarian reasons, could "put people in a position where they make the impossible choice of trying to send their children across the border alone."
There are also worries that people will resort to more dangerous routes if their points of entry are restricted.
But Biden would be responding to something Americans are very concerned about, with immigration ranking as the top issue facing the U.S. for most folks, even more so than the economy, according to a Gallup poll from April.

title: French Military Trainers Could Be Sent to Ukraine in Days: Reports
description: France could send instructors to Ukraine to train its military in a matter of days, according to reports.
content:
France could send instructors to Ukraine to train its military in a matter of days, according to reports.
The development was reported Thursday by French newspaper Le Monde, citing sources familiar with the matter. This came days after Ukraine's top commander, General Oleksandr Syrskyi, said he had signed paperwork permitting France to send military instructors to his country to train Ukrainian forces "and familiarize themselves with their infrastructure and personnel."
France, alongside Ukraine's other NATO allies, has trained more than 100,000 troops since Russia's full-scale invasion began in February 2022, doing so within the European Union. Shortly after Syrskyi's announcement, Ukraine's Defense Ministry issued a "clarification" saying Kyiv was "still in discussions with France and other countries on this."
According to Le Monde's sources, Ukraine was forced to tone down its comments on the possible deployment of French instructors to the war-torn country. Discussions on the matter should accelerate in the coming days, they said, and an announcement could be made during Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's visit to France next week.
France would initially send a few dozen personnel "in order to identify training needs" before deploying several hundred more, the sources said.
Reuters also reported Thursday that France could soon send military trainers to Ukraine, citing three diplomatic sources who said the training would focus on demining, ensuring that equipment stays operational and technical expertise for warplanes, to be provided by Ukraine's Western allies.
"The arrangements are very advanced, and we could expect something next week," one source said.
Newsweek couldn't independently verify the reports on French military trainers and has contacted Russia's Foreign Ministry for comment by email.
French President Emmanuel Macron doubled down in March on the possibility of sending ground troops into Ukraine. In late February, he suggested that NATO members could send in such troops, saying, "We cannot exclude options" because "the security of Europe and the security of the French people is at stake here."
Macron has said there are "no limits" to France's support for Kyiv.
Other NATO members, including the U.S. and Germany, have ruled out sending ground troops to Ukraine. In March, National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby said President Joe Biden has "made it clear that we will not put U.S. boots on the ground."
Russian President Vladimir Putin warned in February that "Russia won't let anyone interfere in its internal affairs" and that his country's "strategic nuclear forces are in a state of full readiness."
Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova told reporters on May 8 that French troops will be targeted by Russian forces if they "appear in the conflict zone [in Ukraine]."

title: Fact Check: Was Giant Mutated Lobster from Nuclear Plant Caught on Film?
description: Unusual sightings of mysterious animals continue to capture the interest and imagination of the public, even when there's no worthwhile evidence that proves they're to be believed.
content:
Unusual sightings of mysterious animals continue to capture the interest and imagination of the public, even when there's no worthwhile evidence that proves they're to be believed.
Earlier this month, allegedly new images of what appeared to be the extinct Australian thylacine (known as the Tasmanian tiger) went viral, even though renowned researchers quickly poured cold water on the sighting.
This week, the image of another strange creature went viral, showing a giant lobster sprawled across a small fishing boat, allegedly caught in the coastline near where the Fukushima power plant disaster took place.
The Claim
A post on X, formerly Twitter, by user @Alphafox, on May 29, 2024, viewed 530,000 times showed a photo of what appeared to be a giant lobster hauled on top of a small boat, alongside three fisherman holding their catch.
The post read: "Caught recently in the waters surrounding the Fukushima nuclear power plant."
The Facts
This photo has been online since at least mid-2023 and is not only fake but the claims linking it to Fukushima have been part of an effort to spread disinformation via Chinese social media apps.
There are a number of tell-tale signs that the image is fake. To start, the horizon at the back of the image is curved, with a land mass that appears to be floating in the air.
The hands and arms of the fishermen are also bent and spread out disproportionately and the boat is asymmetrical.
While it's not referred to as such in the post on X, the creature ostensibly is supposed to be a lobster, but apart from the claws and legs, it looks wildly different from that animal.
No other images of this creature or the story could be found online either, despite the fact that such a haul would be likely to invite local news reports or record achievement prizes.
So, while at first glance the picture might look somewhat real, close inspection quickly pulls its authenticity apart.
There have also been suggestions from other researchers that the image has been misappropriated to help spread disinformation about the effects of the Fukushima disaster.
In 2011, an earthquake and tsunami caused the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Japan to lose power and go into a nuclear meltdown. The plant accumulated around 1.34 million tonnes of water in the decade since, which has been released back into the Pacific Ocean, consistent with international safety standards, since last year.
China has reportedly been opposed to the move, saying it would block seafood imports from Japan despite claims that the water is safe. A Fact Check in September 2023 by Taiwanese fact-checkers found that the image of the giant lobster, and other oversized sea creatures, was being shared on Chinese social networks, tied to stories about Japan's discharge of nuclear wastewater.
The Ruling
False.
This image is not real. There are several tell-tale signs of AI forgery, from a wonky horizon in the distance, to the disproportionate hands and limbs of the fisherman, to the creature's actual appearance.
FACT CHECK BY Newsweek's Fact Check team

title: Americans in One State Get $1,500 Rebate: How to Apply
description: If you live in Minnesota, you could be $1,500 richer—if you apply for a rebate next week.
content:
If you live in Minnesota, you could be $1,500 richer—if you apply for a rebate next week.
The state is offering a rebate worth up to $1,500 if you purchase an e-bike as a discount for 50 to 75 percent of the total cost for the bike and certain accessories.
Read more: What Banks Have 7% Interest on Savings Accounts?
"We've seen many states encourage positive decisions to taxpayers in the form of rebates, and this is not just one of the more creative ones, but also a credit that promotes healthier choices in terms of transportation," Alex Beene, a financial literacy instructor at the University of Tennessee at Martin, told Newsweek.
"The rebate serves Minnesota in multiple ways, by offering residents a more affordable mode of travel, a healthier means of getting around, and hopefully fewer cars in traffic every day. It's a win-win for everyone."
The official online application will open next Wednesday, June 5, at 11 a.m., and checks will be dispersed on a first come, first served basis. Acting fast could be in your favor because Minnesota has warned it will stop accepting applications after 10,000.
In order to properly apply, you'll need to submit your name, date of birth, Social Security number, tax filing status and adjusted gross income from last year.
Read more: Best Place to Put Your Rebate: CD vs. High-Yield Savings Account
There's also a range of requirements you must meet in order to receive the rebate.
For one, you'll have to be at least 15 years old and be a Minnesota resident for the current and previous year. Additionally, you can't be claimed as a dependent for the previous tax year.
As for when the checks go out, Minnesota residents don't necessarily have to wait long. The state said the first round of payments would go out on July 1, with 1,300 checks expected to be issued that day alone.
Another round of rebates will go out in October, with 5,000 denied and the rest placed on the waitlist for the second round.
Read more: Average Savings Account Rates
Minnesota will be prioritizing those with lower incomes during the process, as the state stipulated 40 percent will go to those under a certain range. While people with higher incomes can still apply, they might end up with a lower rebate amount.
If Minnesota finds it still has some leftover money once the second round goes out in October, the thousands who were denied could still be in the running for the free money, but it's not yet clear how popular the rebate will be once the application opens.
In total, Minnesota devoted $2 million to the rebate program.

title: How Grocery Store Loyalty Cards Compare
description: Nearly every grocery store attempts to lure customers in with their loyalty programs, boasting special deals and price savings, but which ones should you truly trust?
content:
Nearly every grocery store attempts to lure customers in with their loyalty programs, boasting special deals and price savings, but which ones should you truly trust?
Inflation stood at 3.4 percent year-over-year at the end of April, and Americans are looking for any way to make their dollar stretch. A big component of that is figuring out how to get the best grocery store deals, and rewards programs are a key way to save money on your weekly trip to the supermarket.
Read more: What Is Inflation? Current Inflation Rate, Causes and How to Stay Ahead of Rising Costs
But not every loyalty program was designed equal to the others, so Newsweek has compiled a list of the top grocery store loyalty cards and how they stack up to each other.
Grocery giant Kroger offers loyalty perks through Boost, but you'll have to spend $59 for the annual membership. Once signed up, you'll receive gas points and free next-day delivery on all your purchases.
"With gas prices still elevated, I advise clients to prioritize grocery loyalty programs with fuel rewards," Michael Ryan, a finance expert and founder of michaelryanmoney.com, told Newsweek. "Even earning just 10-20 cents off per gallon can translate into major savings for families filling up multiple vehicles each week."
Read more: Earn up to 5% Cash Back or More on Your Grocery Purchases
In addition to special deals, Kroger lets shoppers sign up for a Rewards World Elite Mastercard, where 5 percent cashback will be redeemed for the first $3,000 spent, with 2 percent cash back on Kroger purchases and 1 percent on other store purchases.
Another solid loyalty program is available at Giant via the Giant Flexible Rewards program. Like others, you can exchange your points for discounts on your purchases, whether made in store or online.
Immediately upon signing up, you'll earn 500 flexible rewards points, which can be used at Shell gas stations. And for every dollar spent, you earn 1 point, with 100 points earning you $1 in savings. You'll also be privy to exclusive weekly deals and freebies.
Piggly Wiggly, which operates stores across the Southeast, also rewards shoppers with a loyalty program should they choose to sign up.
Through the chain's Pig Points, you can score deals on food and gas on specific items in store.
At the gas station, you earn $1 off every purchase once you achieve 100 points.
Alex Beene, a financial literacy instructor at the University of Tennessee at Martin, echoed the advice that shoppers should specifically look out for the fuel deals, granted free delivery can also be a compelling draw.
"When it comes to grocery store loyalty programs, fuel discounts are usually the gold standard. Grocery stores have both free and pay-for versions of their programs that offer a standard discount on gas that increases as customers spend more," Beene told Newsweek. "However, for most looking for loyalty membership, it's more about free delivery and pick-up."
Publix is also a fan-favorite grocery chain on the loyalty program bandwagon.
The store offers Club Publix, a free program that enables access to personalized deals, birthday freebies and digital savings. Specifically, you'll hear about many buy-one-get-one-free deals and weekly updates on the top sales items.
Perhaps the biggest supermarket chain across the United States, Walmart has not let its loyalty program slide either.
Read more: Capital One Walmart Rewards Mastercard Review
Walmart+, however, is a bit pricier than some of the free options at its competitor stores.
Shoppers will have to fork over $98 to earn 10 cents off each gallon of gas at participating stations as well as free delivery for store orders more than $35. You'll also gain free next-day and two-day shipping from Walmart, and you'll be able to use a contactless checkout option for more easy shopping.
With the perks, the option might make sense if you're a frequent Walmart shopper and the savings would outweigh the $98 yearly fee.
Target, which likely remains Walmart's greatest competitor, has offered similar options through its Circle/REDcard.
The rules are a bit more straightforward: the card gives you a 5 percent discount every time you shop, whether that's in-store or online.
There's also automatic free shipping on most orders, and you can return items after a longer period.
"To maximize your grocery loyalty benefits, don't just sign up and forget about it. Stack those rewards with digital coupons, sales, and cash-back credit card offers," Ryan said. "Many apps let you load digital coupons that are automatically deducted at checkout along with your loyalty discounts. It takes a little effort but can cut your grocery bill by 10 to 20 percent or more."
Shoppers should also consider using a credit card to help boost their grocery store purchase rewards. Several big-name cards offer special cash-back options, which could save you hundreds or even thousands in the long run.
The Blue Cash Preferred Card from American Express, for example, supplies consumers with 6 percent cash back at U.S. supermarkets on up to $6,000 per year in purchases.
Meanwhile, the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card offers three times the points on online grocery purchases, and the Citi Strata Premier Card gives the same three times points but on all supermarket purchases.
Just keep in mind when using a credit card, there are undeniable risks. Shoppers are encouraged to use their credit cards like a debit card and avoid making purchases they wouldn't be able to afford with their monthly income, even if the rewards of using the card are plentiful.

title: Boomer Women Buck Video Game Trend
description: Baby Boomers are playing video games at high rates, but the exact type of Baby Boomer glued to their game console might surprise you.
content:
Baby Boomers are playing video games at high rates, but the exact type of Baby Boomer glued to their game console might surprise you.
"What's been rewarding to see as we dig into the 2024 Essential Facts is that the stereotype of who plays video games doesn't match with reality, and the reality is, everyone plays," Aubrey Quinn, the SVP of Entertainment Software Association, told Newsweek.
While 53 percent of video game players are male and only 46 percent identified as female in the Entertainment Software Association's new report, the gender trend flipped on its head for the older age cohorts.
For Gen Alpha (born 2012-2024), a whopping 82 percent of male respondents said they played video games an hour a week or more, as did 76 percent of girls. Gen Z (1997-2012), millennial (1981-1996) and Gen X (born between 1965 and 1980) age groups, the trend was roughly the same.
By roughly 10 percentage points, the number of men saying they played video games was usually higher among men than women. But Baby Boomers (born 1946-1964) had a different tune.
While half of female Baby Boomers said they played weekly, only 44 percent of Baby Boomer men said the same. And among the Silent Generation (1928-1945), the numbers were about equal, with 30 percent of women playing weekly compared to 29 percent of men.
Keeping your brain sharp is one key reason Baby Boomers and the Silent Generation might be drawn to play video games despite not growing up with them, but why are more women playing than their male counterparts despite the previous gamer stereotypes?
An earlier AARP survey found that the number of older adults playing video games was booming, up from 40.2 million in 2016 to 50.6 million in 2019, and the trend has only escalated.
A higher number of women might look for brain stimulation in their hobbies than their male counterparts in the Boomer and Silent Gen age range, and they also may rely on games to maintain social connections.
"Nearly half of boomers (47 percent) and nearly a third (30 percent) of the silent generation are playing video games regularly," Quinn said. "Older Americans tell us they are more likely to be motivated by keeping their mind sharp than younger gamers, and that's the same for all women despite generation."
Baby Boomers were also the most likely to say video games provide brain stimulation, at 92 percent compared to just 84 percent of Gen Z-ers.
"Games improve my critical thinking skills by giving me a chance to solve complex problems," one anonymous 37-year-old woman said in the report.
The survey also found that gaming was an overwhelmingly white hobby, with 75 percent of players being white compared to just 12 and 19 percent being Black and Hispanic.

title: Home Prices Soar to Record High - These Are the Cities that Rose Fastest
description: U.S. home prices hit another record in March, up 6.5% from a year earlier just as the critical spring buying season began.
content:
U.S. home prices hit another record in March, up 6.5% from a year earlier just as the critical spring buying season began.
Read more: Find the Lowest Rates From Top Mortgage Lenders
The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller U.S. National Home Price Index, which measures home prices across the nation, broke another record in its monthly report, fueled by extremely low inventory that's partly a result of stubbornly high mortgage rates. Many homeowners who locked in rates when they were sitting at 2-3 percent for years are reluctant to list their homes and be forced to take a new loan at 7 percent, which is where rates for a 30-year-fixed mortgage have been hovering for months.
That's exacerbated a major affordability crisis in the housing market, particularly for first-time buyers. While there are some signs that listings have increased in recent weeks as spring kicked into gear—and the average 30-year-fixed rate has eased a bit from recent highs—there are few indications that prices are set to significantly cool anytime soon, especially as the Federal Reserve has pumped the brakes on any plans to cut interest rates in the immediate future.
Read more: How to Get a Mortgage
According to the Case-Shiller data broken down by metro area, San Diego posted the biggest gains among the 20 largest U.S. cities measured. Home prices in the southern California city were up more than 11 percent year-over-year, followed closely by New York, Cleveland and Los Angeles. Prices in the 20-city index were up 7.4 percent on an annual basis, slightly above the 7.3 percent gain a month earlier and evidence that demand for homes in urban areas — where inventory remains especially tight — remains strong.
On a month-over-month basis, the 0.3 percent rise in March was less than the 0.6 percent rise in February.
The Northeast region was the "top performer" with an 8.3 percent annual rise in prices, said Brian D. Luke, head of commodities, real and digital assets at S&P Dow Jones Indices, in a press release. "COVID was a boom for Sunbelt markets, but the bigger gains the last couple of years have been the northern metro cities."
Read more: How to Buy a House With Bad Credit
It's the ninth time national home prices have hit a new high in the past year, Luke said, and all 20 of the biggest markets have now seen price gains for four months straight.
In a sign of just how competitive the Northeast market remains even in the face of high rates, a 1,000-square-foot, 2-bedroom, 1-bathroom fixer-upper in Bergen County, N.J., outside of New York City, received 79 offers when it was listed for $398,000 in late March. The house sold for $137,000 over ask this month.

title: Canned Cocktail Backed by Jay-Z's Venture Capital Firm Taking US By Storm
description: The venture capital firm backed by Jay-Z is making its way into the red-hot canned cocktail industry, backing a beloved gin-based concoction from Finland that's seeing explosive growth in the U.S. and a growing list of celebrity endorsers.
content:
The venture capital firm backed by Jay-Z is making its way into the red-hot canned cocktail industry, backing a beloved gin-based concoction from Finland that's seeing explosive growth in the U.S. and a growing list of celebrity endorsers.
Last week, Marcy Venture Partners announced it was making a "significant" investment into the ready-to-drink Finnish Long Drink brand.
The actor Miles Teller, DJ Kygo, former Boston Bruins goalie Tuuka Rask and professional golfer Rickie Fowler are already partners with the maker of the sipper that's long been popular in its namesake country.
"I became an investor in The Finnish Long Drink because I think it's the best in the market and has an authentic backstory," Teller said when he increased his investment stake at the beginning of last year. "It's high-quality stuff and I think consumers deserve a product that's good and refreshing."
The celebrity partnerships and investments will help Finnish Long Drink (the brand) expand its "store footprint and marketing efforts," according to co-founder and CEO Evan Burns.
"It was clear Marcy Ventures saw the same big potential we do in the brand to bring Finland's best kept secret to more Americans," Burns told Newsweek.
"It was love at first sip. Just have a taste and it's clear why this national treasure of Finland is now storming North America," Larry Marcus, the co-founder and managing director of Marcy Ventures, told Newsweek. The firm has not disclosed the specifics of its investment.
According to CB Insights, Finnish Long Drink has now raised over $41 million across 14 rounds of funding.
The venture capital firm backed by Jay-Z's investment is significant because of his billion-dollar track record in the alcohol space.
Last year, he sold his controlling interest in D'USSE Cognac to Bacardi for $750 million.
Marcy Venture Partners' portfolio include investments in Rihanna's Savage X Fenty lingerie line, streetwear marketplace StockX and robot-powered Stellar Pizza.
In 1952, Finland was preparing to receive an influx in tourists for the Helsinki Summer Olympics. In order to help vendors handle the new wave of thirsty customers, Alkoholiliike, the national alcoholic beverage retailing monopoly, introduced two brands of pre-mixed, ready-to-drink gin cocktails known in Finland as "long drinks." (That's the "legend of 1952" reference printed on each Finnish Long Drink can.)
In Finland, the "long drink," or "lonkero" which literally means tentacle, is commonly made with grapefruit soda and gin, though many add touches like cranberry juice and lime.
After Finland joined the European Union in 1995, the government was no longer allowed to control the production of the drinks on its own, and several long drink brands were born.
Despite the cocktail's popularity overseas — it's also sold in China, Japan and Taiwan — it's path in the U.S., where the canned cocktail and hard seltzer market has become extraordinarily crowded, is far from certain. Boston Beer, the alcohol behemoth and parent company of Sam Adams, tried marketing a brand called Bevy Long Drink that was pulled off shelves last year due to lack of sales.
Still, the beverage maker has already seen staggering growth stateside, selling 1.8 million cases last year, up from 33,000 in 2019. Sales grew 114 percent from 2021 to 2022, the company told Newsweek. Through mid-April, retail sales were up 92 percent year-over-year, according to NielsenIQ data. Burns said the company sold over 100 million cans in that period.
"Our ambition is to ten times the size of the business," Burns said. "People may find that crazy, but the data supports it's possible."
Finnish Long Drink's off-premise sales — such as grocery and liquor stores — have seen triple-digit growth in the last year, per NielsenIQ, far outpacing similar canned cocktails made by better-known brands like Bacardi and Jack Daniel, which also benefit from far greater distribution.
The company also touts the "highest net promoter score in alcohol," according to Burns. He said 91 percent of Finnish Long Drink's customers are likely to recommend the beverage to a friend.
"Most people don't realize that Long Drinks are bigger to Finns than Guinness is to the Irish," Burns said.
Now Burns is eyeing this summer as a coming out party of sorts for the brand in the U.S.
"People are obsessed with the taste, and once they're introduced to what long drinks are and have the chance to try it, they fall in love," he said.
"It really is like nothing else in the market — the taste is uniquely refreshing which makes Long Drink perfect for a hot summer day be it lakeside, at the beach or by the pool."
Update: 5/25/2024, 9:30 p.m.: This article and headline has been updated for clarity.

title: What Is Manganese? Metal That Sparked Fiji Water Bottle Recall
description: The FDA recently issued an update regarding a previous recall of Fiji Natural Artesian Water bottles over concerns they were contaminated with manganese. But what is manganese, and why is it a health risk?
content:
The FDA recently issued an update regarding a previous recall of Fiji Natural Artesian Water bottles over concerns they were contaminated with manganese. But what is manganese, and why is it a health risk?
Manganese is a common, naturally occurring mineral found in rocks, soil, and natural water sources. It is also an essential nutrient—found in a range of foods, including nuts, seeds and green, leafy vegetables—that supports a range of important bodily functions, such as bone health, reproductive health, immunity and wound healing.
However, it is possible to have too much of a good thing. Chronic, excessive exposure to the element can result in a neurological condition called manganism. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, manganism symptoms are similar to those of Parkinson's disease and include trembling, stiffness, slow movement and depression. Additional symptoms, as listed by the National Institutes of Health, can include mania, insomnia, delusion, hearing loss and memory problems.
The U.K. government's Health Protection Agency said high manganese exposure could also affect brain development in children.
In March, the FDA announced a recall of over 70,000 cases of Fiji Natural Artesian Water bottles over concerns they were contaminated with manganese and three types of bacteria. The FDA has since lowered the classification of the water bottle recall to one that is "not likely to cause adverse health consequences."
Welders and people who work in steel factories are the most at risk of developing manganism because of the high levels of exposure in their working environment. However, manganese exposure can also occur through drinking water because of the natural mineral deposits in groundwater.
The Environmental Protection Agency has determined that in drinking water, manganese concentrations below 1 milligram per liter for up to 10 days are unlikely to cause any adverse health effects, even in children, the CDC reports. However, the FDA says manganese concentrations in bottled drinking water should not exceed 0.05 milligrams per liter.
Newsweek has contacted the FDA via email and Fiji via its website for comment.
In a post on X, formerly Twitter, Fiji responded to questions regarding the March recall, writing: "We learned of a quality issue affecting select FIJI Water 500mL (24-Pack) cases with PRD dates of Nov. 11, 2023, Nov. 12, 2023, Nov. 13, 2023, Nov. 24, 2023, and Nov. 25, 2023 sold through Amazon.com."
The brand added in a separate post: "The notice sent by Amazon does not accurately reflect the issue. We were notified of a quality issue with complaints of discoloration in select product with PRD dates of Nov. 11, 12, 13, 2023, and Nov. 24, 25, 2023."
"FIJI Water remains safe to buy and consume," the brand said. "This is a quality issue only affecting the specific lots sold on Amazon.com between February 1, 2024 and March 3, 2024 with PRD dates of Nov. 11, 2023, Nov. 12, 2023, Nov. 13, 2023, Nov. 24, 2023, and Nov. 25, 2023."
Is there a health problem that's worrying you? Let us know via health@newsweek.com. We can ask experts for advice, and your story could be featured on Newsweek.

title: Connecticut Map Shows Where State Could Be Underwater From Sea Level Rise
description: An interactive map shows how Connecticut may be affected by sea level rise as climate change worsens.
content:
An interactive map shows how Connecticut may be affected by sea level rise as climate change worsens.
The projections by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration are incorporated in a national map showing that rising sea levels could encroach on several areas of the state. The map allows the viewer to see how different parts of the U.S., as well as individual states, may be affected if sea levels rise by different amounts up to 10 feet. It also calculates how populated areas would fare amid the rising levels.
Areas marked in blue show the areas of Connecticut that could be submerged if sea levels do not stop rising.
Connecticut is just one state facing significant challenges as sea levels continue to rise because of climate change. Coastal communities are particularly at risk. A combination of increasing temperatures, melting ice caps and thermal expansion of seawater is contributing to accelerated sea level rise, which is expected to have profound effects on the state.
Over 61 percent of the state's population resides in coastal areas, according to the state's Department of Energy and Environmental Protection, and nearly 30 percent work within these regions.
Neighboring states New Jersey and New York are also at risk. In fact, the map shows that much of the Eastern U.S. would be inundated with water if sea levels were to rise by just 3 feet.
At that point, water would start to go inland toward Connecticut's capital, Hartford, the map shows.
A report from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said the United States is expected to experience as much sea level rise in the next 30 years as it did over the entire past century. This projection indicates that Connecticut's shoreline could see an additional 8 to 10 inches of sea level rise by 2050, with the worst-case scenario predicting up to 15 inches.
High-tide flooding is already a concern in coastal Connecticut cities like New London and Bridgeport. These areas are experiencing more frequent flooding events, which are expected to increase as sea levels rise, according to data from the Yale Center on Climate Change and Health.
Connecticut's response to sea level rise involves a combination of local initiatives and state-level planning. The state's adopted sea level change scenario predicts a rise of 1 foot 8 inches by 2050. This guides municipalities in preparing evacuation plans, hazard mitigation strategies and revisions to conservation and development plans.
Connecticut has taken significant steps to prepare for the impact of sea level rise caused by climate change. Several projects involving community engagement, scientific research and strategic planning aim to enhance the state's resilience and protect its coastal communities from the increasing threat of flooding and rising tides.

title: Mystery of Unique Double Moon Shines Light on Planet Formation
description: An asteroid floating in our solar system has been discovered to have a very weird and unique double moon—and it might just change the way we think about how planets form.
content:
An asteroid floating in our solar system has been discovered to have a very weird and unique double moon—and it might just change the way we think about how planets form.
The asteroid—officially titled "Dinkinesh" but nicknamed "Dinky"—was found to have a tiny moon orbiting it when NASA's Lucy spacecraft flew past it in November 2023. However, subsequent data revealed that the moon is actually two moons stuck together, marking the first time such a system has been observed around an asteroid.
Now, a new paper in the journal Nature has revealed how this moon—known as a contact binary—may have formed, shedding light on how celestial bodies interact.
"Our ultimate goal is to understand the formation of celestial bodies," study co-author Jessica Sunshine, a professor of astronomy at the University of Maryland, said in a statement. "How do planets form? How was Earth formed? We know that big planets are formed by smaller bodies, so studying these little asteroids lets us see how materials behave and interact on a smaller scale. With Dinky and the other asteroids we're flying by, we're laying the groundwork for understanding how planets are made."
Dinkinesh is situated in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, and measures about 2,360 feet across. As Lucy approached the asteroid, it saw that its moon—named Selam—was actually two small moons joined together. Each of these two moons were around the same size at about 700 feet across, which is a rare trait among the other scant contact binaries we have seen in our solar system.
Selam takes around 52.5 hours to orbit Dinkinesh, with an incredibly short distance of just under 2 miles between the two. The researchers estimate that Dinkinesh has a mass of about 16 times that of Selam.
"There's a lot more complexity in these small bodies than we originally thought," said Sunshine. "With the additional observations taken by the spacecraft, we were able to better analyze features such as Dinkinesh's rotation speed and Selam's orbit pattern. We also have a better understanding of what materials they're possibly made of, bringing us a step closer to learning just how terrestrial bodies are created."
The Lucy spacecraft's high-resolution imaging system, L'LORRI, captured detailed images of Dinkinesh and Selam, revealing a trough and a ridge on Dinkinesh's surface. These features suggest that a portion of Dinkinesh's material was ejected into space due to its fast rotation and the bright glare of the sun.
The researchers theorize that this ejecta could possibly have led to the formation of Selam, with the rest showering back down onto the asteroid to form the ridges seen on the surface of Dinkinesh.
In the paper, the researchers note that this discovery offers new insights into the formation and structural dynamics of celestial bodies, challenging current theories and opening up new avenues for research into how systems like Dinkinesh's form and evolve.
"One of the things that's critical to understanding how planets like Earth got here is understanding how objects behave when they hit each other, and to understand that we need to understand their strength," co-author Hal Levison, a researcher at Southwest Research Institute, Boulder, Colorado, said in a statement.
"Basically, the planets formed when [smaller objects like asteroids] orbiting the sun ran into each other. Whether objects break apart when they hit or stick together has a lot to do with their strength and internal structure."
The findings also have potential for comparative studies with the asteroid Didymos and its companion, which was also explored by NASA's DART mission. Despite being in different regions—Dinkinesh in the main asteroid belt and Didymos near Earth—both systems exhibit striking similarities.
"I'm personally very excited to compare the Didymos binary system with this one, especially as they appear to share many similarities such as size, general shape and possibly composition despite being in totally different parts of the solar system," Sunshine said.
"The Didymos binary system is located in a near-Earth environment while the Dinkinesh system is located much farther away from Earth in the main asteroid belt," she said. "They have very different features but we think they may have undergone similar processes to become what we know of them today."
The Lucy mission, launched in October 2021, aims to explore 11 asteroids over its 12-year journey, focusing primarily on the Trojan asteroids orbiting near Jupiter. Dinkinesh was a warm-up target added to the mission's schedule, demonstrating the spacecraft's capabilities and setting the stage for more ambitious encounters in the future. After a gravity-assist flyby of Earth in December 2024, Lucy will head towards another main belt asteroid, Donaldjohanson in 2025, before moving on to the Trojan asteroids in 2027.

title: Lake Mead Water Level Has Zero Risk of Falling Below 1,000 Feet Before 2028
description: Lake Mead's projections are improving following two consecutive wet winters, with zero risk of falling below 1,000 feet before 2028, new Bureau of Reclamation figures show.
content:
Lake Mead's projections are improving following two consecutive wet winters, with zero risk of falling below 1,000 feet before 2028, new Bureau of Reclamation figures show.
The figures, released on May 29, show the Nevada-Arizona reservoir's five-year outlook much improved. The projections are updated three times a year and show a range of scenarios that influence potential water use cuts based on varying reservoir levels.
One key takeaway from the latest projections is the zero percent chance that Lake Mead will fall below 1,000 feet before 2028. This is a notable improvement from January's projection, which estimated a 3 percent chance.
However, the projections also show a 13 percent chance that the reservoir could fall below 1,020 feet by 2028, a figure that remains unchanged from January. The lowest recorded elevation for Lake Mead was 1,040.58 feet in 2022, highlighting the ongoing risks despite recent improvements. The variability in the projections underscores the impact of weather conditions, which can significantly alter the reservoir's future.
Any changes in Lake Mead's water levels are important, as in recent years, the reservoir, which stores water for 25 million people living in the region, has fallen well below average.
In July 2022, the lake reached a record low of 1,040 feet, the lowest it has been since it was first constructed in the 1930s. This was mainly due to prolonged drought conditions that plagued the southwestern U.S. for years.
These conditions, paired with the region's overconsumption of water, meant that water resources were being used more quickly than they were being replenished.
The five-year projections are even more important as the 2007 Colorado River interim guidelines are set to expire in 2026. Alongside this, two groups of Colorado River states continue to debate how to manage the ongoing water scarcity crisis, including the operational strategies for reservoir releases.
The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation is expected to release a two-year projection in mid-June that will determine whether Nevada needs to implement further water usage cuts. Last year, Nevada had to reduce its Colorado River allotment by an additional 4,000 acre-feet based on June's projection.
While the latest projections offer some hope for improved conditions at Lake Mead, the broader context of climate variability and interstate water politics suggests that significant challenges remain. The upcoming two-year projection will be a critical indicator for southern Nevada, potentially influencing water management decisions for the near future.

title: Newsweek Hosts Panel on the Future of Life Sciences at BIO Convention 2024
description: We are in the midst of a historic moment in the life sciences sector. After an initial wave of interest during the coronavirus pandemic, the health care and pharmaceutical industries saw a drastic drop in investment.
content:
We are in the midst of a historic moment in the life sciences sector. After an initial wave of interest during the coronavirus pandemic, the health care and pharmaceutical industries saw a drastic drop in investment.
However, since the start of 2024, the tides have turned yet again as innovations in AI, personalized medicine and gene-based therapies promise to revolutionize the life science industry.
To dive deeper into these developments, Newsweek will be hosting a panel discussion at the upcoming BIO International Convention in San Diego on June 3. This is one of the largest, most-comprehensive events for the biotech industry, attended by over 20,000 industry leaders from across the globe.
Newsweek's affiliate event sees Senior Science Reporter Pandora Dewan joined by five industry experts to discuss the promises and challenges of these future innovations and, most importantly, how they can be delivered to those who need them.
"Newsweek is deeply committed to facilitating inspirational conversations that foster respectful debate and welcome diverse opinions," Dev Pragad, Newsweek CEO, said. "Our goal is to drive meaningful change across various sectors, and I am particularly excited about the transformative power of life science—especially within the biotech and pharmaceutical industries.
"These fields hold transformative potential for global health and innovation, and we see significant opportunities for Newsweek to contribute to public discourse and education on these advancements," Pragad added.
The event also marks the launch of Newsweek's annual report, The New Era of Life Sciences, featuring industry insights from the CEOs of Pfizer, Regeneron, Eli Lilly, and others.
The panel will feature:
Amit Shah, Executive Vice President of Newsweek International, who has managed the event, described it as a "game-changer" for small- and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurs. "It's a platform where they can amplify their voices, connect with experts, and reach a massive audience on Newsweek."
Shah added: "Let's empower and inspire each other to reach greater heights in the thrilling realm of science."
The panel will take place at 1 p.m. EST on Monday, June 3. In-person attendance is fully booked, but you will be available to watch the panel on Newsweek's YouTube channel after the event.
Update 05/30/2024, 11:35 a.m. ET: This article was updated with additional comment from Amit Shah.

title: F1 News: Lewis Hamilton Recounts Chilling Moment He Thought 'It Was All Over'
description: During the latest episode of "Hot Ones," Seven-time Formula 1 world champion, Lewis Hamilton, shared an alarming recount of his near-death experience while surfing at Pipeline in Hawaii, a location notorious for its formidable waves. The champion diverged from racing tracks to tackle 20-foot waves, describing a moment when he believed "it was all over."
content:
During the latest episode of "Hot Ones," Seven-time Formula 1 world champion, Lewis Hamilton, shared an alarming recount of his near-death experience while surfing at Pipeline in Hawaii, a location notorious for its formidable waves. The champion diverged from racing tracks to tackle 20-foot waves, describing a moment when he believed "it was all over."
The harrowing incident underscores the risks extreme sports pose even to seasoned athletes like Hamilton. Surfing with professional Kelly Slater—who warned him of the dangerous conditions—highlights the level of challenge and thrill-seeking inherent in Hamilton's off-track activities.
Hamilton recounted being advised against entering the water due to the overwhelming surfing conditions at Pipeline. Ignoring the risks, he plunged into the waters, only to find himself struggling in the "kill zone," an area so fraught with danger that one wrong move could be catastrophic. He explained:
"Biggest wipeout I had I was with Kelly Slater, on Pipeline. It was like 20ft waves and Kelly was like 'there's no way you're coming out there. You're crazy.'
"I turn around and see this set of four waves coming and that for me was like: 'it's over, it's all over.' As I threw my board, I dove down and grabbed the reef and I could hear this wave crash behind me. My board got ripped and snapped in half.
"I came back up, obviously gasping for air and the next one was coming so back down, grabbed the reef again as another wave comes over. So I did that three times. I got up, I'd nearly run out of air. I'd nearly drowned, but managed to swim back from there."
Speaking about his passion for surfing during an interview with DAZN in 2021, Hamilton commented (translated by Google):
"It's my favorite sport. There are no phones, you merge with nature and feel more connected than ever to the world. That's the best feeling ever.
"I'm crazy because I always try to get on the big waves. I try to go under the wave, go up, go from one side to the other, but I'm not able to, obviously. Normally I have to swim a lot.
"The last time I went, I paddled out to a wave the size of this building. It was incredible. I had never experienced anything so terrifying. But I didn't catch the wave, I stayed on the side watching. That day, my board broke in two, I lost it... It was something intense."

title: New York Yankees' Star Pitcher Suffers Long-Term Injury
description: The New York Yankees' historic rotation will be without one of its best players for the foreseeable future.
content:
The New York Yankees' historic rotation will be without one of its best players for the foreseeable future.
More news: Yankees Starting Rotation Makes MLB History, Even Without Gerrit Cole
On Thursday, the Yankees placed right-handed pitcher Clarke Schmidt on the 15-day injured list with a right lat strain. However, he's going to be out significantly longer than the minimum two weeks.
Yankees manager Aaron Boone spoke to reporters ahead of the team's series finale against the Los Angeles Angeles on Thursday, and said Schmidt won't throw for 4-6 weeks. Schmidt had an MRI on Wednesday, saw Dr. Neal ElAttrache on Thursday, and they determined "it's going to be a while" until Schmidt returns to the mound. Obviously, if Clarke isn't throwing for 4-6 weeks, it's going to be significantly longer until he's back with the ball club.
This is a huge blow for the Yankees and their dominant rotation. The Yankees are in the midst of MLB history with 16 consecutive starts of five or more innings while allowing two or fewer runs. This streak began back on May 12 and has continued through Wednesday night's 2-1 win over the Angels.
Schmidt has made three dominant starts over the last few weeks, which have contributed to a breakout year for the 28-year-old out of Acworth, Georgia.
The former first-round pick in 2017 has made 11 starts this season and has a 2.52 ERA, which is top 10 in the American League among qualified pitchers.
However, he'll now miss a good chunk of the season and will be replaced by right-handed pitcher Cody Poteet for now, according to Boone.
There may be a new replacement on the horizon, though...
While the Clark injury is tough news for the Yankees and their rotation, Boone did have an exciting update on the status of right-handed pitcher Gerrit Cole.
Cole, who hasn't pitched this season due to elbow discomfort, has been nearing a return and could make a rehab assignment as soon as this coming week, per Chris Kirschner of The Athletic.
More news: MLB Power Rankings: Yankees Rise, Dodgers and Rangers Plummet in Another Wild Week
Cole will likely need multiple rehab starts before he's able to return, but this puts him in line to return sometime in June, which has been the hope all along.
Cole made an appearance at Yankee Stadium last week in which he threw a 20-pitch live batting practice session, and came out of it feeling great. The next step will be a few rehab assignments, and then the reigning American League Cy Young award winner will be able to return to the Yankees.
